metadata.title: “Slow sites have a negative impact on revenue”: Publishers opt for leaner websites to attract and keep users on site | What’s New in Publishing | Digital Publishing News
metadata.description: Publishers looking to deliver more value to their readers, may inadvertently do so at the cost of user experience. “In our shared pursuit to push the web to do more, we’re running into a common problem: performance. “Sites have more features than ever before. So much so, that many sites now struggl…
metadata.author: Faisal Kalim
metadata.publisher: What’s New in Publishing | Digital Publishing News

metadata.title: Google just got better at understanding your trickiest searches
metadata.description: A new machine learning algorithm is helping Google tell which words in queries matter most—and how they relate to each other.
metadata.author: Harry McCracken

metadata.title: The Google Feature Magnifying Disinformation
metadata.description: Google’s knowledge panels contain helpful facts and tidbits. But sometimes they surface bad information, too.
metadata.author: Lora Kelley

metadata.title: Is Boris Johnson really trying to game Google search results?
metadata.description: Could admissions around buses, kissing kippers and saying he’s the “model of restraint” really downplay negative search results? It’s unlikely to be a longterm tactic
metadata.author: Chris Stokel-Walker

metadata.title: The far right is dominating the information wars through “keyword signaling”
metadata.description: It’s an old story: someone searches Google for a common keyword — “jews,” “women,” “black people” — and gets back a bunch of far-right conspira…
metadata.author: Cory Doctorow

metadata.title: Google readies new markup rules for European news publishers - Search Engine Land
metadata.description: The approach is a reaction to the EU Copyright Directive, to avoid paying licensing fees.
metadata.author: Greg Sterling

sections: It's worth remembering that speed matters to websites: it boost your SEO and your reader retention:
Google's been moving away from keywords as a central plank of SEO for some time. This new algorithm is just going to accelerate those changes.
The attempts by political operators to manipulate people through social media is well-discussed. However, we're seeing more and more evidence that the same is being done to search.
The EU Copyright Directive might have a big impact on how your work appears:
